name: Pondicherry
fun_fact: Fun fact: Pondicherry remained French until 1954 - nine years after India's independence - and the city is literally divided into two halves: the French Quarter (Ville Blanche) with pastel colonial buildings and the Indian Quarter (Ville Noire). Street signs are still in French and Tamil, and locals speak both languages fluently

hero_dishes.name: Pondicherry Fish Assad Curry (Creole)
hero_dishes.description: The quintessential Pondy dish - coconut milk-laden fish curry flavored with star anise, curry leaves, and finished with lime. It's neither fully French nor fully Tamil - it's pure Creole fusion
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from 250 years of French-Tamil intermarriage and cultural blending. French colonists married local women who adapted French techniques to Tamil ingredients. The result is Creole cuisine - a dying art that older residents now teach in cooking classes to preserve these fading recipes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Villa Shanti (14 Suffren Street, White Town), Le Dupleix (Suffren Street), local Creole cooking classes in French Quarter homes

hero_dishes.name: Meen Puyabaise (Tamil Bouillabaisse)
hero_dishes.description: French bouillabaisse transformed with turmeric, tamarind, and coconut milk - chunks of local fish in a golden-orange broth that's both familiar and completely foreign to French palates
hero_dishes.origin_story: When French sailors craved their homeland's seafood stew, Tamil cooks recreated it with local spices. Traditional Marseille bouillabaisse got a South Indian makeover with curry leaves and kokum. It became so popular that even French residents preferred this version
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Villa Shanti (European-Asian fusion), Le CafÃ© (Goubert Ave Beach Road), Bay of Buddha (White Town with ocean views)

hero_dishes.name: Kadugu Yerra (Mustard Prawn)
hero_dishes.description: Plump local prawns cooked in a thick gravy where French mustard seeds meet Tamil coconut - the sharp, earthy kick of mustard balanced by sweet coconut base
hero_dishes.origin_story: The perfect symbol of Pondicherry's dual soul. French colonists brought their love of Dijon mustard, while coastal Tamil cooks relied on coconut for everything. Someone combined them, and magic happened. This dish exists nowhere else in the world
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kasha Ki Aasha (23 Surcouf Street - European fusion), local Creole restaurants, Villa Shanti

hero_dishes.name: French Croissants and Baguettes
hero_dishes.description: Authentic French pastries made daily - buttery, flaky croissants and crusty baguettes that transport you straight to Paris, but served with Tamil filter coffee
hero_dishes.origin_story: French bakers taught local apprentices who kept the traditions alive even after 1954. Pondicherry is the only place in India where you can get genuinely authentic French bread and pastries, made using techniques passed down for generations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Baker Street (Bussy Street - famous for croissants and gourmet sandwiches), The Indian Kaffe Express (123 Bussy Street - coffee and crepes), Le CafÃ© (Beach Road)

signature_drinks.name: French Filter Coffee (CafÃ© au Lait meets Tamil Filter Coffee)
signature_drinks.description: A hybrid brew - French cafÃ© au lait technique applied to South Indian filter coffee beans, creating a drink that's neither French nor Tamil but uniquely Pondy
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in traditional French cups but made with Tamil Peaberry beans. Locals drink it at breakfast with croissants, combining the best of both worlds. The older generation still prefers traditional 'meter coffee' poured from great heights

signature_drinks.name: Pondicherry Beer and French Wine
signature_drinks.description: Local craft beer from Pondicherry breweries alongside French wines that are easier to find here than anywhere else in India due to the city's import privileges
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beer with Tamil meals, wine with French dinners - often at the same restaurant. Pondicherry has more relaxed alcohol laws than other parts of India, inherited from French times. Seaside cafes serve chilled rosÃ© with sunset views

food_culture_notes: Creole cuisine is sadly dying out - younger generations prefer pure French or pure Indian food, not the hybrid dishes their grandparents created
You can eat a French croissant for breakfast, Creole fish curry for lunch, and Tamil thali for dinner, all within a few blocks
The French Quarter has yellow buildings with blue shutters - mandatory colonial-era color codes still enforced today
Nearby Auroville (founded 1968) is an experimental international township promoting unity and sustainable living, adding another layer of global fusion to the food scene

landmarks: French Quarter (Ville Blanche) with pastel colonial buildings
Promenade Beach and Gandhi statue (one of Asia's biggest)
Sri Aurobindo Ashram on Rue de la Marine
Auroville's Matri Mandir (golden spherical meditation center)
atmosphere: French Quarter cafes with wicker chairs

pastel pink and mint green (painted facades)
